section.name: Clearly conveys the purpose, and the content is well-aligned towards this intent

values.desc: No
Minimally
Partially
Completely

values.name: a
values.desc: Clearly stated what the audience should gain from the communication

values.name: b
values.desc: Used each part of the communication to convey or support the main message

values.name: c
values.desc: Concluded by summarizing what was to be learned

values.name: a)
values.desc: Decide if your main purpose is to inform, to persuade, to argue, to summarize, to entertain, to inspire, etc.

values.name: b)
values.desc: Write out the intent of the communication you are creating and refer back to it as you generate your material.

values.name: c)
values.desc: Make sure the purpose of the communication is presented early to orient your audience to the focus of the communication.

values.name: d)
values.desc: Check that the focus of each segment is clearly linked to the main message or intent of the communication.

values.name: e)
values.desc: Summarize the main ideas to wrap up the presentation (refer back to the initial statement(s) of what was to be learned).

section.name: Uses language and delivery style that is consistent with the norms of the subject area and suitable for the audience

values.desc: No evidence
Rarely
Sometimes
Consistently

values.name: a
values.desc: Communicated to the full range of the audience, including noivces and those

values.name: b
values.desc: Aligned the communication with interests and background of the particular audience

values.name: c
values.desc: Used vocabulary that aligned with the discipline and was understood by the audience

values.name: a)
values.desc: Identify the range and level of expertise and interest your audience has for the topic and design your communication to have aspects that will engage all members of the audience.

values.name: b)
values.desc: Identify what the audience needs to know to understand the narrative.

values.name: c)
values.desc: Plan how you will interpret key data or details in a meaningful way for non-experts.

values.name: d)
values.desc: Only use jargon when it is understood readily by most members of your audience, and it makes the communication more effective and succinct.

values.name: e)
values.desc: Check that the vocabulary, sentence structure, and tone used in your communication is aligned with the level of your audience..

values.name: e)
values.desc: Collect feedback from others on drafts to make sure the core message of the communication is easily understood.

section.name: Presents ideas in a logical and cohesive manner

values.desc: No evidence
Rarely
Sometimes
Consistently

values.name: a
values.desc: There was a clear story arc that moved the communication foward

values.name: b
values.desc: Organizational cues and transitions clearly indicated the structure of the communication

values.name: c
values.desc: Sequence of ideas flowed in an order that was easy to follow

values.name: a)
values.desc: Consider the ‘story’ that you want to tell. Ask yourself what’s the main message you want the audience to leave with.

values.name: b)
values.desc: Identify the critical points for the story (do this before you prepare the actual communication) and map out the key points.

values.name: c)
values.desc: Summarize sections before transitioning to the next topic.

values.name: d)
values.desc: Repeat key ideas to ensure the audience can follow the main idea.

values.name: e)
values.desc: Make sure that you introduce prerequisite information early in the communication.

values.name: f)
values.desc: Try more than one order for the topics, to see if overall flow is improved.

section.name: Constructs and uses visual representations effectively and appropriately

values.desc: No evidence
Rarely
Sometimes
Consistently

values.name: a
values.desc: Each figure conveyed a clear message

values.name: b
values.desc: Details of visual representation were easily interpreted by the audience

values.name: c
values.desc: The use of visual enhanced understanding by the audience

values.name: a)
values.desc: Plan what types of figures are needed to support the narrative - consider writing out a figure description before you construct it.

values.name: b)
values.desc: Avoid including unnecessary details that detract from the intended message.

values.name: c)
values.desc: Consider how many messages each visual is trying to convey and divide up if the complexity or density is overwhelming.

values.name: d)
values.desc: Be sure labels, text, and small details can be easily read.

values.name: e)
values.desc: Provide a caption that helps interpret the key aspects of the visual.

values.name: f)
values.desc: Seek feedback on visuals to gauge initial reaction and ease of interpretation.

section.name: Selects a format style that enhances the effectiveness of the communication

values.desc: No evidence
Rarely
Sometimes
Consistently

values.name: a
values.desc: Stylistic elements were aesthetically pleasing and did not distract from the message

values.name: b
values.desc: Stylistic elements were designed to make the communication accessible to the audience (size, colors, contrasts, etc.)

values.name: c
values.desc: The level of formality of the communication aligns with the setting, context, and purpose

values.name: a)
values.desc: Use titles (headers) and subtitles (subheaders) to orient the audience and help them follow the narrative.

values.name: b)
values.desc: Look at pages or slides as a whole for an easy-to-read layout, such as white space, headers, line spacing, etc.

values.name: c)
values.desc: Use emphases where needed to direct audience attention to important aspects.

values.name: d)
values.desc: Use colors to carefully highlight or call attention to key elements to enhance your narrative without distracting from your message.

values.name: e)
values.desc: Make sure that text, figures, and colors are readable and accessible for all.

values.name: f)
values.desc: Seek feedback to confirm that the language, tone, and style of your communication match the level of formality needed for your context and purpose.

section.name: Uses expected writing conventions for the form of communication

values.desc: No evidence
Rarely
Sometimes
Consistently

values.name: a
values.desc: Writing contained correct spelling, word choice, punctuation, captialization

values.name: b
values.desc: All phrases and sentences were grammatically correct

values.name: c
values.desc: All paragraphs (or slides) were well constructed around a central idea

values.name: d
values.desc: All figures and tables were called out in the narrative, and sources were correctly cited

values.name: a)
values.desc: Proofread your writing for spelling errors, punctuation, autocorrects, etc.

values.name: b)
values.desc: Review sentence structure for subject-verb agreement, consistent tense, run on sentences, and other structural problems.

values.name: c)
values.desc: Verify that items in lists are parallel.

values.name: d)
values.desc: List the themes of each paragraph (or slide). If there are more than 2, consider starting a new paragraph (or slide).

values.name: e)
values.desc: Confirm that each figure, table, etc has been numbered consecutively and has been called out and discussed further in the narrative.

values.name: f)
values.desc: Confirm that all work that has been published elsewhere or ideas/data that were not generated by the author(s) has been properly cited using appropriate convetions.

values.name: g)
values.desc: Ask someone else to review and provide feedback on your work.

section.name: Uses voice and body language to convey the intended message in a clear and engaging manner

values.desc: No evidence
Rarely
Sometimes
Consistently

values.name: a
values.desc: Spoke loudly and clearly with a tone that indicated confidence and interest in the subject

values.name: b
values.desc: Vocal tone and pacing helped maintain audience interest

values.name: c
values.desc: Gestures and visual cues further oriented the audience to focus on particular items or messages

values.name: d
values.desc: Body language directed the elivery toward the audience and indicated the speaker was open to engagement.

values.name: a)
values.desc: Practice for others or record your talk;

values.name: i.
values.desc: be sure that your voice can be heard, and your word pronunciations are clear.

values.name: ii.
values.desc: listen for “ums”, “like”, or other verbal tics/filler words that can detract from your message.

values.name: iii.
values.desc: observe your natural body language, gestures, and stance in front of the audience to be sure that they express confidence and enhance your message.

values.name: b)
values.desc: Add variety to your speed or vocal tone to emphasize key points or transitions.

values.name: c)
values.desc: Try to communicate/engage as if telling a story or having a conversation with the audience.

values.name: d)
values.desc: Face the audience and do not look continuously at the screen or notes.

values.name: e)
values.desc: Make eye contact with multiple members of the audience.
